Based on all information and articles I've seen so far, the Zuma missions sounds more like an intentional PR attack against SpaceX considering this is done before the Falcon Heavy. The corporates within the ULA wishes to eliminate a successful rival who has the technology to corner the rocket launch market. If I had to hazard a guess, I would guess it is some sort of hypersonic spaceplane technology test. It's not in orbit, apparently (unless it has some sort of reduced observability capabilities,) and SpaceX says "mission accomplished" so one explanation that explains both those facts is that it was intended to go skipping off the upper layers of the atmosphere. If they were testing a hypersonic ramjet or something with a similar function, that's what they would do. So in that event, SpaceX would be able to say the mission was a success on their end and yet not deliver their customer's payload to orbit because it was never intended for orbit.

This whole blame/no-blame thing stinks of current WH incompetence, but that raises another question: can a US President order a spy satellite to be launched ASAP? The fact that this was rushed makes me not surprised that something would go wrong.

Probably the most valid criticism of SpaceX I've heard in this case, though, is the assertion that launch providers are responsible for tip-to-tail inspections and performance of a flight. While that may to some degree be accurate:
1. As Everyday Astronaut notes, we don't know it was actually a failure. Seems like it was, maybe. Maybe not. The only thing we can say for sure is "we don't know"
2. If it WAS a failure, we don't know what the failure was. I won't rehash what EA says, but I will restate point 1. "We don't know".
3. Classified payloads are a little bit of a different story. SpaceX may not have been given clearance to inspect the whole setup. And all signs point to an 11th hour delivery of the payload prior to launch, so even if they did inspect it, they weren't given a lot of time to do so. Probably intentionally. SpaceX isn't the manufacturer or the customer so while their leash is longer than ours, information-wise, it's only just a bit longer.

There may have been some tip-to-tail responsibility here, but maybe not. Again, to be totally redundant, "we don't know".

Speaking to the matter of why SpaceX did not stop or delay the deorbiting of the second stage if something was wrong with payload detachment, we must also consider the fact that the second stage has a very limited life span due to its batteries, and it was not intended for an extended duration geostationary transfer orbit mission. It's unlikely that it could have remained operational much past the planned deorbit burn anyway. Leaving a dead second stage in orbit with a classified payload attached to it would probably be a far worse idea than simply going ahead with the normal flightplan, which also neatly disposes of the classified payload to prevent any other nations from inspecting it in orbit.
